properties.Title: Blowing Snow Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow combined with strong northwesterly winds will reduce visibilities to near zero Monday. ### Blowing snow advisories are issued when winds are expected to create blowing snow giving poor visibility to 800 metres or less for at least 3 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2021-03-01T12:59:42-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-02-28T21:00:42-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1011196790.2021

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Southerly winds will reach up to 90 kilometres per hour late this evening and overnight tonight. ### Damage to buildings, such as to roof shingles and windows, may occur. High winds may toss loose objects or cause tree branches to break. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2021-03-01T13:02:50-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-02-28T21:03:50-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1505541458.2021

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Wind chill values of approximately minus 40 are expected beginning Monday and continuing Tuesday. An Arctic air mass combined with moderate winds will produce extreme cold conditions. ### Watch for cold related symptoms: shortness of breath, chest pain, muscle pain and weakness, numbness and colour change in fingers and toes. Extreme cold warnings are issued when very cold temperatures or wind chill creates an elevated risk to health such as frost bite and hypothermia. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2021-03-01T13:00:32-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-02-28T21:01:32-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1985441933.2021

properties.Title: Winter Storm Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snowfall Tuesday Snowfall amounts may possibly exceed 25 centimetres beginning early Tuesday morning. Strong easterly winds combined with snow are expected to reduce visibilities to zero in the blowing snow. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Winter storm watches are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2021-03-01T13:17:44-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-02-28T21:18:44-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3938379516.2021
Area: Blanc-Sablon
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds tonight and Monday. Strong northwest winds gusting up to 80 km/h are forecast to develop late this evening along the shorelines of northern Lake Huron, northern Georgian Bay and eastern Lake Superior. Winds will then diminish slightly overnight but are expected to strengthen again Monday morning. Gusts up to 80 km/h will be possible again Monday morning into the early afternoon. The winds will diminish Monday evening. Strong winds can throw loose objects, cause tree branches to break, and may cause property damage. Power outages are also possible. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2021-03-01T12:51:13-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-02-28T20:52:13-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3197311768.2021
Area: Searchmont - Montreal River Harbour - Batchawana Bay, Blind River - Thessalon, Espanola - Killarney
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Weather Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Winter Weather Travel Advisory in effect for tonight. Snowfall with total amounts of 10 to 15 cm is expected. Snow, at times heavy, will affect parts of northeastern Ontario tonight. Additionally, strong northwest winds gusting up to 70 km/h will develop this evening creating localized areas of blowing snow. Dangerous winter driving conditions due to heavy snow and blowing snow are expected. Be prepared to adjust your driving with the changing road conditions. Conditions are expected to improve by Monday morning. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2021-03-01T12:50:20-00:00

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Blizzard conditions are expected to end this evening. Some blowing snow may continue until overnight. ### Travel is expected to be extremely hazardous due to reduced visibility. Blizzard warnings are issued when widespread reduced visibilities of 400 metres or less are expected for at least 6 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.

properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A prolonged period of extremely cold wind chills between minus 55 and minus 60 is expected to begin overnight. Extreme cold conditions will last through much of the coming week and will likely expand into other parts of the Kitikmeot though the period. ### Watch for cold related symptoms: shortness of breath, chest pain, muscle pain and weakness, numbness and colour change in fingers and toes. Extreme cold warnings are issued when very cold temperatures or wind chill creates an elevated risk to health such as frost bite and hypothermia. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.
Expires: 2021-03-01T13:17:45-00:00

Area: Gjoa Haven
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Flash Freeze Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rain or wet snow are expected this evening as temperatures remain above the zero degree celsius mark. Temperatures will then fall rapidly with the passage of a cold front near or after midnight. Ponding water, slush, and any falling precipitation will freeze as the temperature drops. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become icy and slippery. Travel may be hazardous due to sudden changes in the weather. Flash freeze warnings are issued when a rapid drop in temperature is expected, that can cause water from rain or melted snow on streets and sidewalks to quickly freeze. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2021-03-01T05:56:50-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-02-28T20:57:50-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3637813279.2021

properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds tonight. Potentially damaging winds Monday. Strong west to northwesterly winds gusting up to 80 km/h are forecast to develop this evening along the shore of Lake Huron. Winds will likely diminish slightly Monday morning but will strengthen again Monday afternoon. Gusts up to 90 km/h will be possible Monday afternoon. The winds are forecast to diminish Monday evening. Power outages are possible. ### Damage to buildings, such as to roof shingles and windows, may occur. High winds may toss loose objects or cause tree branches to break. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Snow Squall Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow squalls possible on Monday. Locally heavy snow squalls are forecast to develop early Monday with the arrival of an unseasonably cold airmass. Locally heavy snowfall amounts of 10 to 15 cm will be possible by the time the snow squalls weaken Monday evening. Strong northwesterly winds will also accompany the snow squalls, resulting in reduced visibilities at times in heavy snow and blowing snow. Motorists should prepare for adverse winter driving conditions and adjust their travel plans accordingly. ### Snow squalls cause weather conditions to vary considerably; changes from clear skies to heavy snow within just a few kilometres are common. Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Snow squall watches are issued when conditions are favourable for the formation of bands of snow that could produce intense accumulating snow or near zero visibilities. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2021-03-01T12:36:59-00:00

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snowfall expected beginning early Tuesday morning. Locations: most of Newfoundland. Total snowfall: 10 to 15 cm or more, especially on the Great Northern Peninsula and Baie Verte Peninsula. Maximum wind gusts: 80 to 100 km/h or higher. Time span: Tuesday. Remarks: Snow is expected to spread across Newfoundland on Tuesday, in combination with strong southeasterly winds and blowing snow. The snow may change to rain or freezing rain over southern parts of the island during the early-afternoon. Conditions will improve Tuesday afternoon or evening. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

properties.Title: Wreckhouse Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Very strong wind gusts are expected or occurring Maximum gusts: southeasterly up to 140 km/h in the Wreckhouse area. Time span: Monday evening until Tuesday morning. Remarks: Southeasterly winds gusting to 100 km/h will develop Monday evening then increase to 140 km/h overnight. Winds will ease upon shifting to strong southwesterly Tuesday morning. ### Drivers may lose control of their vehicles; tall vehicles are at risk of being overturned. Wreckhouse wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

properties.Title: Les Suêtes Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Very strong wind gusts that may cause damage are expected or occurring. Maximum Les Suetes gusts: 130 km/h. Time span: Monday afternoon until Monday night. ### Damage to buildings, such as to roof shingles and windows, may occur. High winds may result in power outages and fallen tree branches. Les Suêtes wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
Expires: 2021-03-01T11:41:41-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-02-28T19:42:41-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2224268629.2021
Area: Inverness County - Mabou and north
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: High southerly winds will reach up to 100 kilometres per hour and diminish late in the night. ### Loose objects may be tossed by the wind and cause injury or damage. Wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2021-03-01T14:31:38-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-02-28T22:32:38-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1411826545.2021
Area: Salluit
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 15 to 25 cm is expected. Time span: Monday morning until Monday night. Locations: northern New Brunswick Remarks: snow, heavy at times, will spread eastward across northern New Brunswick beginning early Monday morning. Temperatures will rise above zero in some places Monday afternoon which will cause partial melting of the snow as it falls, which could make it heavy to move. Snow tapers to flurries Tuesday morning then strong northerlies develop which ushers in a very cold airmass. Some blowing snow is possible on Tuesday morning. ### Rapidly accumulating snow will make travel difficult. Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NBStorm.
Expires: 2021-03-01T11:40:38-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-02-28T19:41:38-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1369627288.2021
Area: Edmundston and Madawaska County, western half of Restigouche County, Campbellton and eastern half of Restigouche County, Grand Falls and Victoria County, Mount Carleton - Renous Highway, Bathurst and Chaleur Region, Miramichi and area, Acadian Peninsula
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Hazardous winter conditions are expected. Snowfall: 10 to 20 cm, except near 5 cm along parts of the coast. Maximum wind gusts: 80 km/h, except up to 120 in areas prone to enhanced southeasterlies. Locations: western Newfoundland. Time span: Monday evening until Tuesday morning. Remarks: Snow, very strong southeasterly winds and reduced visibilities in blowing snow will begin Monday evening and continue into Tuesday. Snowfall amounts will range from 5 to 10 cm along the coast to 20 cm over higher terrain by Tuesday morning with more snow expected on Tuesday. Local enhancement in southeasterly flow typically occurs in the vicinities of Cape St. George, Port au Port Bay, the outer Bay of Islands, Bonne Bay, Western Brook Pond and St. Pauls Bay. ### Visibility will be suddenly reduced to near zero at times in heavy snow and blowing snow. Winter storm warnings are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2021-03-01T11:18:40-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-02-28T19:19:40-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1486954136.2021
Area: Corner Brook and vicinity, Deer Lake - Humber Valley, Gros Morne, Bay St. George, Parson's Pond - Hawke's Bay
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A period of very cold wind chills is expected. Wind chill values between minus 45 and minus 50 are expected to develop tonight and continue until Monday afternoon. ### Extreme cold warnings are issued when very cold temperatures or wind chill creates an elevated risk to health such as frost bite and hypothermia. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2021-03-01T13:06:34-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-02-28T21:07:34-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3982748058.2021
Area: Attawapiskat, Fort Severn, Peawanuck, Sachigo Lake - Bearskin Lake, Big Trout Lake - Kasabonika, Webequie
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A period of very cold wind chills is expected. Southwesterly winds near 20 km/h combined with temperatures in the mid minus thirties will result in wind chill values of -50 or lower overnight into Monday morning. Wind chill values are expected to moderate by Monday afternoon. ### Watch for cold related symptoms: shortness of breath, chest pain, muscle pain and weakness, numbness and colour change in fingers and toes. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.
Expires: 2021-03-01T12:39:01-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-02-28T20:40:01-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2865012251.2021
Area: Clyde River
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 15 to 25 cm is expected. Time span: late Monday afternoon until Monday night. Locations: Magdalen Islands. Remarks: snow, heavy at times, will develop over the islands beginning late Monday afternoon and likely change over to a few rain showers Monday night. Strong northwesterly winds will develop Tuesday behind the storm. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
Expires: 2021-03-01T11:41:09-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-02-28T19:42:09-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1305309361.2021
Area: Îles-de-la-Madeleine
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A period of very cold wind chills is expected. Light north winds combined with temperatures in the mid minus forties will result in wind chill values of -55 or lower overnight into Monday morning. Wind chill values will moderate slightly Monday afternoon however extreme wind chill values are expected to return to the area Monday night into Tuesday morning. ### Watch for cold related symptoms: shortness of breath, chest pain, muscle pain and weakness, numbness and colour change in fingers and toes. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.
Expires: 2021-03-01T12:38:15-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-02-28T20:39:15-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.4130662419.2021
Area: Sanirajak
